849004.name: Lumpy Slippers
849004.notes_html: These slippers were designed for people with swollen, sore feet that have a hard time finding shoes that don’t make the discomfort worse. They are long lasting and easy to wash. My mom has been wearing a pair since November of last year, and they are still in great condition. The shoes were made to be rather large to accommodate the swelling that happens throughout the day.

859047.name: Braille Shawl
859047.gauge_description: 24 stitches and 30 rows = 4 inches in stocking stitch
859047.notes_html:
This shawl was designed in celebration of the centenary birthday of Nelson Mandela, affectionately known as Madiba. The shawl features a quotation by this great man, written in Braille along the border. The quotation provides the following inspiration:

“I have learned that courage was not the absence of fear, but the triumph over it.”

The pattern is based on traditional Xhosa dress (Umbaco) designs, which are characterised by circular collars and alternating bands of light and dark.

A donation will be made on behalf of each sale to the Pioneer School for the blind. You can read more about their work at www.pioneerschool.org.za.

UPDATE 11 September 18: We raised enough to pay for one child’s school clothes for a year. Thank you for your support!

The shawl is semi-circular in shape and is knitted in nine sections from the top down.

You will use four skeins of fingering weight yarn to complete the shawl, two in a dark colour and two in a light colour.

867374.name: Braillegenser // Braille sweater
867374.notes_html:
SIZES
XXS (XS) S (M) L (XL) XXL

MEASUREMENTS
The sweater is oversized, approximately 20 cm
wider than your actual bust width. I recommend comparing the measurements in the pattern with a sweater that has the ease you would like, particularly if you wish the sweater to be smaller or larger than stated in the pattern.
Width: 110 (115) 120 (125) 130 (135) 140 cm
Length: 55 (55) 57 (57) 59 (61) 63 cm
Sleeve length: 45 cm or desired length

YARN
The sweater is knit with two strands of yarn held to- gether. For a more airy version, use only one strand of Rauma Vams Pt3 – but please pay attention to the gauge and note that you will use more yarn than stated in the pattern.
Rauma Vams Pt3 (100% Norwegian wool. 83 m per 50 grams) 400 (400) 450 (500) 500 (550) 550 grams Rauma Alpaca Silk (65% Babyalpaca, 10% extra fine merino, 25% silk. 200 m per 25 grams) 100 (100) 100 (100) 125 (125) 125 grams

NEEDLES
8 mm and 6 mm, or the needle size you need to obtain the stated gauge

GAUGE
12 stitches = 10 cm in stockinette

The sweater has an oversized fit with seamed sleeves and
no shoulder shaping, giving it a t-shirt shape. It fits equally well for women and men. The body is worked in the round until you divide for front and back pieces. The braille writing
is knitted into the front and back pieces. Pick your favourite word - use the empty chart to play around with the braille.

875320.name: Your Majesty Socks
875320.sizes_available: 8” circumference x 7.5” foot length x 8.25” leg height
875320.gauge_description: 24 stitches and 44 rows = 4 inches in Stockinette
875320.notes_html:
Your Majesty is a simple sock pattern featuring a “princess sole” and a cute duplicate stitch crown design at the top.
The pattern is worked toe up with a reverse stockinette sole, a short row heel and the option of ribbing or picot edging around the top. The smoothness of the sole is ideal for those with feet too sensitive for traditional stockinette socks.

Skill level
Beginner

Finished Measurements
8” circumference x 7.5” foot length x 8.25” leg height
If Picot Edging is worked, leg height is 7.75”
The pattern includes 1 standard size along with tips on how to customise the size and elements of the pattern to your liking.

Techniques Used
Working in the round, knitting, purling, increasing (LLI, RLI, LPI, RPI), decreasing (K2tog, SSK, P2tog, SSP), duplicate stitch, magic loop, Judy’s Magic Cast On, Short Row Heel.

Yarn
Sample pictured used:
Knit Picks Gloss Fingering (70% Merino Wool, 30% Silk; 220 yards/50g);
MC – Robot 25015 (Approx. 220 yards req)
C1 – Honey 25377 (Approx. 10 yards req)
C2 – Cranberry 25378 (Approx. 10 yards req)

Needles
US 3 (3.25mm) DPNs or circular needle for Magic Loop technique, or size to obtain gauge.

Gauge
24 sts and 44 rnds = 4” in stockinette st, in the round, blocked.

Pattern Support
violetlebeaux@gmail.com

894730.name: Both Sides Now And Then
894730.gauge_description: 32 stitches and 44 rows = 4 inches in st st, in the round
894730.notes_html:
Leg & Foot Length: adjustable to fit
Choose a size with a circumference about
1 inch/2.5 cm smaller than your actual foot circumference, measured around the ball of your foot.
******
Have you heard of the Princess Sole? Some knitters like to work their socks so that the sole is worn knit-side on the inside, for comfort underfoot. This is an entire Princess Sock. Worked with the knit side facing, for speed and ease, but designed to be worn with the purl side out, for maximum comfort. Or not.

The heel flap and turn are worked with a reinforcement pattern, arranged so that the floats from the slipped stitches lie on the knit side of the sock. If you choose to wear them knit side out, the pattern is rather fetching and unusual. And the gusset stitches are worked up as a pick-up-and-purl. This has a rather pleasing effect: if worn purl side out, the ridge is hidden, if worn knit side out, the ridge looks like a knit column, aligned with the reinforcement pattern.

This design features some of my favourite details:
• a Dutch (a.k.a. square) heel turn, that allows you to work reinforcement on the back of the heel and continue it down into the heel turn.
• a no-graft toe
• a simple but very effective pattern stitch that works well worn either way

users.about_me:
I'm a teacher and designer based in Toronto.

I'm Knitty's Lead Technical Editor. I contribute regularly to books and magazines.

I've also written nine (!) books; one more is coming in 2024.

I'm known for my "small start" approach to teaching sock and mitten knitting, and a rigorous and possibly terrifying mathematical approach to everything.   

I'm absolutely a process knitter -- the bigger the challenge, the better.

954858.name: Instant Winter Socks (Cuff Down)
954858.sizes_available: 3 adult sizes (by circumference), any length. Choose a size with about 1in/ 2.5cm of negative ease: 7in/ 18cm (shown), 8.5in/ 22cm, 10in/ 26cm.
954858.notes_html:
Create marled socks in custom colors using two strands of sock yarn. The perfect socks for cold feet, fast gifts, or impatient knitters. Plus, a fun solution to “buying too much sock yarn”. Great winter boot socks, and ideal for padding around the house on frosty mornings. Get started on a cozy project today!

These extra quick ribbed cuff-down socks feature a Strong heel (with optional contrast heel) and short-row toes. In 3 adult sizes with full written instructions, customization ideas, resizing guidelines, and a brief Kitchener stitch tutorial.

Toe up version also available.

Yarn: Knit with 2 strands of sock/ fingering weight yarn (yarn held double). Total will depend on length, two 100g skeins will be sufficient for most lengths.
Shown in: (C1) ”Lang Super Soxx Nature 4 Ply”, in “Plum”, and (C2) “Valley Yarns Huntington” in “Mustard”.
Or, try one self-striping & one solid strand, leftovers, or a single strand of DK yarn knit at the same gauge.
Gauge: In stockinette stitch: 22sts/ 4in, 22sts/ 10cm (5.5sts/ 1in).
In pattern: 22sts/ 4in, 22sts/ 10cm (5.5sts/ 1in).
Stockinette row gauge: 30 rows/ 4in, 30 rows/ 10cm (7.5 rows/ 1in).
Needles: In size needed to obtain gauge, I used US size 3/ 3.25mm. Pattern utilizes stitch counts and markers to adapt to your preferred needle configuration (DPN, magic loop, etc).
Notions: 3 stitch markers, tapestry needle, scissors.
Sizes: 3 adult sizes (by circumference), any length. Choose a size with about 1in/ 2.5cm of negative ease. 7in/ 18cm (shown), 8.5in/ 22cm, 10in/ 26cm. See “Customize” section for additional sizes/gauges.

Skills: knit, purl, knit in the rnd (using your preferred needle configuration such as: DPNs, magic loop, two-at-a-time, etc), slip stitches, M1 inc, SSK dec, K2tog dec, P2tog dec, long tail cast on (or your preferred stretchy cast on), work in pattern as established, short rows, wrap & turn, and Kitchener stitch (includes brief tutorial).
Accessibility Notes: Pattern features: 12 point san-serif font with bolded 14 point headings, no columns (except abbreviation key). Due to additional thickness & warmth, they may be particularly useful to those with circulatory problems (such as Raynauds). Also nice when reversed, if “princess soles” are preferred.

982279.gauge_pattern: Adult Sizes: Make a square 10 sc by 10 rows
982279.name: Lil' Bug Soft Packer
982279.gauge_description: 10 stitches and 10 rows = 2 inches in Adult Sizes: Make a square 10 sc by 10 rows
982279.notes_html:
The Lil’ Bug Pattern:
This pattern is for a soft packer for use by trans and non-binary folks, or as an anatomical model. Includes 4 sizes: Adult S, L and XL, and the Bitty Bug for youths.

  • 4 Sizes
  • Full photo tutorial
  • Sized, shaped and stuffed to be anatomically proximal
  • Designed by a member of the trans community
  • Tested by the trans and non-binary community

The Lil’ Bug story:
In October 2019 I was looking for a pattern to make a soft packer for myself, after being frustrated by the cost and discomfort of silicone options.

Silicone packers are expensive, heavy, and can get hot, sticky and uncomfortable. They come in limited sizes and colors, and unless worn with a strap, they weigh down clothing and don’t stay put. They have to be powdered and cared for carefully, and even then only last about 6 months with daily wear.

The crochet options I found were oversized and comical, not designed to look good or be comfortable under clothing. I started to think making my own pattern might be necessary. I tried the free patterns I could find, and posted some photos in a large LGBTQ+ sewing group. Immediately I had 2 parents ask me if I could please make something like this for their young trans sons. After hearing from a mother who didn’t know what else to do than just cry with her son, unsure how to ease his dysphoria with no options available for children, I decided to add the youth size to my pattern. The very first Bitty Bug packers I made were for 10 and 6 year old boys. I’m honored to have been a small part of their gender journey.

I went on a mission to make a quality, comfortable packer that could be available to anyone in any shape, color, or size, and that they could make themselves. I designed, tested and refined the Lil’ Bug with a group of friends and wonderful, experienced crochet testers. I sent them out to trans people to road test, and wore them myself. The resulting design is functional, comfortable, visually appropriate, and most importantly, feels good to wear. The presence that a packer has when worn is the most important part for most folks of addressing dysphoria.

Why isn’t this pattern free?
It is important to pay marginalized people for their creative work, and these small sales help support my queer family by covering a small part of the cost of providing packers for free. Accessibility is important to me, and if anyone needs it for free, please contact me.

Ways to Participate
I am committed to helping my community have access to the things we want and need. I hope you enjoy this pattern, and for those of you making these for trans friends and family - you rock!

Want to make packers for the trans community?
The Parts For People Volunteer Facebook group
The Soft Packer Project Ravelry group

982660.name: Knit Packer
982660.notes_html:
This pattern came about as a result of several conversations between good friends and fantastic allies. After a discussion on a facebook group, in which a member shared their work to help a good friend in a difficult situation, my good friend Janet and I started talking.

I came out in 2015, and have been excited to share my discoveries and understandings of my gender as I’ve grown, and I’ve been very lucky to have friends who are not only keen to understand, but are happy to help the community whenever possible. The facebook post prompted a discussion about what packers are and how they help the trans community. Through this we discovered a need within the trans community, a need that knitting and crochet could alleviate.
Now, several of us are working to get 65 packers and 20 pairs of breast forms in time for this holiday season.

Now you’re probably wondering what this pattern is.

A Knit Packer is a gender affirming item that is worn to create the silhouette in your jeans. Typically these can be worn by trans and non-binary folks for a variety of reasons, one of which is to mitigate gender dysphoria.

Elastomer or silicone packers are expensive, difficult to source, and behind barriers such as only available online. While yes this item appears to be rather mature, the product itself is not. It’s designed with the idea in mind that someone out there could use a packer.

They take very little time to knit up, are versatile in size and stuffyness depending on your choice as you knit them. Be aware that should you decide to create something bigger, the fabric of the knit piece should remain tight to prevent stuffing from pushing out through the stitches.

Also this packer lets you decide if that’s something you’re comfortable with wearing. Better to try something free before spending money.

A Crochet Pattern is available Here

This pattern will always remain free. If you have any questions feel free to get in touch with me. All photos used with permission from their creator, Lady Octavia.

984003.name: Monsieur Louis
984003.gauge_description: 24 stitches and 32 rows = 4 inches in st. st.
984003.notes_html:
Pay-as-you-can Sytem: All patterns from Les Caspérides offer a 15% discount when needed with the code: Welcome

This pattern is available in English (English description below)

Ce patron est disponible en français

Este patrón es escrito en español/castillano

FR

Description

Monsieur Louis (40x30 cm) est un tour de cou dont le délicat motif de nopes forme une phrase en braille.

La phrase écrite est : Avec le bon sens, je vois la vie en rose

Le patron comprend les explications pour le réaliser en fingering tricotée avec deux fils en même temps comme avec un seul fil de dk, ainsi que deux vitesses de lecture (débutant.e.s + confirmé.e.s). Les points importants bénéficient de tutoriels vidéo.

Construction

Monsieur Louis se construit sans couture, du haut vers le bas, en rond.

Échantillon

L’échantillon est de 24x32.

Tailles

Le patron propose une taille unique dont les dimensions finales sont de 40x30 cm.
Le patron explique comment raccourcir le tour de cou et/ou comment l’élargir, et donne des indications pour des échantillons différents.

Laine et métrage

1 écheveau de Baroque Single Les Caspérides (65% merino superwash, 20% soie, 15% yak, 480m/120g) ou 1 écheveau (2 pelotes) soit 100g de laine fingering tricotée double ou dk tricotée simple.

Le modèle de présentation a été tricoté double dans le coloris Monsieur Louis et a nécessité 80g soit 320m

Aiguilles

4 mm

! Il ne s’agit là que d’une suggestion : la taille d’aiguille est déterminée par l’échantillon.

Matériel

1 marqueur de début de rang + 3 marqueurs
1 aiguille à laine pour rabattre souplement

EN

Description

Monsieur Louis (40x30 cm/15.7x11.8 inch.) is a snood which delicate bubbles design hides a sentence in Braille. the tactile written sytem invented by Louis Braille (reason why its name is Monsieur Louis).

The hidden message is: Avec le bon sens, je vois la vie en rose (With the right sense, I see life in pink) !this pattern being a tribute to the French Louis Braille, the sentence remains written in French even in the English version.

The pattern provides instructions to knit it in fingering with two strands held together and in dk with only one, as well as two reading rythmes (beginners + experts).
Video tutorials are here to help you get the best out of your project!

Construction

Monsieur Louis is seamless. We knit it top-down in the round.

Gauge

Gauge is 24x32.

Size

Monsieur Louis provides a unique size, 40x30 cm/15.7x11.8 inch., yet includes tips to make it shorter and/or larger, as well as indications to different gauges.

Yarn and yardage

1 skein of Baroque Single Les Caspérides (65% merino superwash, 20% silk, 15% yak, 480m-527 y./120g) or 1 skein (2 balls) of fingering or dk.

The presentation model is in the colour Monsieur Louis and uses 80g/320m-350 y.

Needles

4 mm/US 6 or any size that gives you the gauge

Material

1 BORmarker + 3 markers
1 tapestry needle for bind-off

pattern_author.name: Les Caspérides
pattern_author.notes:
> Pay-as-you-can System: all patterns
> from Les Caspérides offer a 15%
> discount if needed with the code:
> Welcome

###**EN**
Les Caspérides is a knitting patterns & hand-dyed yarns company from Dresden, Germany. The name is inspired by a fictive stellar constellation, tribute to the famous 19th century painter Caspar David Friedrich.  He is the author of the beautiful "Wanderer above the Sea of Fog", a romantic landscape inspired by the nature in the Dresden countryside.

All Les Caspérides patterns belong to permanent collections organised around designs or memories.


###**FR**
Les Caspérides, ce sont des patrons, mais c’est également de la laine teinte à la main avec des pigments écologiques. C’est aussi et surtout une constellation fictive inspirée d’un peintre bien réel, Caspar David Friedrich, auquel on doit notamment « Le Voyageur contemplant une mer de nuages », tableau devant lequel mon émotion ne s’est jamais démentie. Le hasard a fait que j’habite désormais sa ville, non pas celle où il est né mais celle dans laquelle il a choisi de vivre, Dresden. 

Tout l’univers Les Caspérides rend hommage à la peinture, à l’art, aux voyages, en réalité, à tout ce qui est du domaine du sensible. C’est pourquoi les patrons sont classés en collections permanentes, comme dans un musée. Dans chacune, plusieurs patrons gravitent autour du même thème, d’une même idée, d’un même motif, et viennent chacun à leur manière l’influencer, le façonner et l’enrichir.

984286.name: JT Necktie
984286.gauge_description: 34 stitches and 20 rows = 4 inches in Herringbone Knit Stitch
984286.notes_html:
The JT Necktie is an adaptive knitwear pattern. It’s designed with a faux knot and an elastic neck for individuals with limited dexterity or mobility that may not be able to tie a traditional necktie. The fit can be customized to fit multiple sizes and ages. Once the tie is customized, it simply slips on and off via the elastic neck. Never tie a tie again!

The pattern is one size fits most, but includes instructions for make the tie longer or shorter to accommodate different heights. It’s knit up in herringbone stitch with an I-cord edging for a finished look. This is an intermediate knitting pattern. Required skills include yarn overs, I-cord, and basic assembly. The tie is finished with an elastic nick that requires either hand or machine sewing.

I selected Caron Simply Soft for this design so that it’s washable and allergy free.

Yarn Requirements
80-100 yds / 73 - 92 m of worsted weight, cat 4 yarn

Yarn Shown in Sample
Caron Simply Soft

Needles
6 mm / US 10

Gauge
34 sts and 20 rows in herringbone stitch

pattern_author.name: Liz Sheffield
pattern_author.notes:
Hi!  I’m Liz, the designer behind Different View Designs.  After my Mom got diagnosed with ALS, I was frustrated and overwhelmed by feeling like there was nothing I could do for her as she fought this disease. When she passed away I dedicate my business to serving individuals that needed assistance dressing or had limited dexterity.  My pieces are beautiful, because I passionately believe that no one should have to choose between functionality and feeling great in their clothes.  Each piece is then designed with thoughtful details to make it easier to wear or put on.
My first piece, the Marilue Cowl, is dedicated to my mother.
A few of my pieces are still available for free on my website, see individual listings for more info.

986552.name: Quick & Easy Round Knocker
986552.gauge_description: 4.5 stitches and 3.5 rows = 1 inch in half double crochet
986552.notes_html:
For the full backstory on this pattern, why I wrote it, and our campaign to create five dozen knockers and almost two dozen pairs of knockers for the 2019 holidays, have a look at the companion pattern: Perfectly Reasonable Packer.

There are several good knocker patterns already available, both on Rav and elsewhere, but for the most part they use single crochet, which I find slow and laborious. Since we’re trying to make 20 pairs of these - which means 40 individual knockers - in a short amount of time, I wanted something with far more instant gratification. I like half double crochet because it creates a dense enough fabric much faster than single crochet.

I also found the patterns I had on hand confusing and difficult to follow. I’m not a very experienced crocheter, so I wanted something easy to follow AND faster to produce. What I particularly like about this pattern is that, once you know how to spot the increases and decreases in the fabric, you don’t need to count any more. I am big on not counting!

986825.name: Unplanned Extubation Prevention Mitts
986825.notes_html:
I designed this pattern according to the specifications provided by the health care workers in the Neonatal Intensive Care Unit at a local children’s hospital, and have been making these mitts for several years. Often times these are the only clothing items that the babies wear, aside from their diapers. There is also some anecdotal evidence that these mittens contribute to improved outcomes for these wee humans through a reduction in the number of times they accidentally pull out their equipment (e.g., breathing or feeding tubes, IV or central lines, monitoring leads).

This is also a great way to use those small bits of leftover sock yarns!

988405.name: Senior socks with handles
988405.gauge_description: 22 stitches  = 4 inches in Stockinette in the round
988405.notes_html:
These socks were designed for my elderly grandfather who is not as agile as he used to be. Therefore I decided to put handles on them, at the top of the cuff, to make it easier for him to put them on.

This is not a detailed pattern for making toe-up socks but rather a description of how I made the socks with referral to the techniques I have used. Only the part about the handles is detailed.

My socks were knit in worsted weight yarn with 200 m /217 yds for 100g. They fit European size 44, appx 28 cm / 7¼ in long.

Knitting icord and icord bind off are techniques that are used.

Dessa sockor skapades till min gamla morfar som inte är lika rörlig som han varit. Därför bestämde jag mig för att göra handtag längst upp på skaften för att göra det lättare för honom att sätta dem på sig.

Det här är inte ett detaljerat mönster på hur man stickar sockar från tån och upp utan snarare en beskrivning på hur jag gjorde morfars sockar och vilka tekniker jag använt. Det är bara själva handtagen som jag beskrivit detaljerat.

Morfars sockar är stickade i raggsocksgarn med ca 200 m per 100 g. De passar fotstorlek 44, med fotlängd ca 28 cm.

I-cord och i-cordavmaskning är tekniker som används.

Two pattern options available.

Premium pattern includes images as well as detailed instructions and creator notes on how to customize your own packer.

Unlike silicone models or sock models. This offers more flexibility during movement, more air circulation to reduce sweating during daily use. The balls in the sack move independently for a more realistic appearance and feel.

Basic pattern is text instructions only. Not for inexperienced pattern readers or crocheters.

1006146.name: I Love You in Braille
1006146.gauge_description: 15 stitches and 12 rows = 4 inches in HDC or HTR
1006146.notes_html:
When I was small I watched a gentleman reading from a Braille book and I found it utterly fascinating! When I looked closely I thought it a true marvel that with a series of bumps that to my eye looked so similar could spell out the letters and words that made my love of reading possible. It pleased me to know that my love of reading was not restricted to those who have their sight.

Crochet is also a marvel to me. That with yarn and a hook all sorts of outcomes are possible! I found the creation of bumps in crochet very interesting as I love texture and with a little exercise of the little grey cells this pattern emerged.

A message to someone you love with a little bit of intrigue or perhaps for that person you know who has limited or no vision but you would love to give something special to. We get so much joy with our knitting and crochet projects, so this textural number was created for those who benefit more from touch!

There is a US terminology version as well as a UK/AU version for download (because let’s face it… who likes to accidentally use the wrong stitch!)

Finished measurement: 8” (20cm) wide x 8 ¼” (21cm) long but easily customisable. A very easy way to make a smaller or larger cloth is to use lighter or heavier weight yarn and corresponding hook although please be mindful that this will affect amount of yarn required.

Yarn: About 45g or 78.8 yards (72 meters) of Aran weight (10ply 8wpi) yarn,100% cotton.

Hook Size: US 8/H/ UK 6 / 5mm

US Gauge: 15 HDC x 12 HDC rows = 4”
UK Gauge: 15 HTR x 12 HTR rows = 10cm

pattern_author.name: Angie Cooper
pattern_author.notes:
.
**Knitwegian** is the brand for my designs.

I'm constantly amazed at how some yarn and a hook or needles can create interesting outcomes! 

I love texture and am inspired by nature (both human and the natural world) and hope to continue to grow and incorporate these elements into my designs. 

I am grateful to the nurturing and creative community on Ravelry and the wonderful distraction and immense growth that I have experienced over the last few years courtesy of the constant upward and forward movement found here.

Thank you for stopping by, I look forward to seeing your projects!

Come and join our community in my [Ravelry Group][1] for pattern support, KALs (Knit-Alongs), test knits and new pattern announcements.

Please share your projects on Instagram [@Knitwegian][2] so we can show some love!


  [1]: https://www.ravelry.com/groups/angie-cooper---knitwegian
  [2]: https://www.instagram.com/knitwegian/

users.fave_colors: Greens (especially olive), oranges (rusts and pumpkin type oranges), yellows (especially mustard & Ochre), dark, vibrant teal. I love wearing shades of warm neutrals and brown. When it comes to other colours I like the  deep & rich tones.
users.about_me:
[APQ Link][1]

https://www.ravelry.com/wiki/pages/UsingTheTextEditor
[Ways to shape an Asymmetrical shawl][2]

**Techniques**
[Jacquard Invisible Floats][3]
[Kitchener Stitch][4]

**2020 goals**
Only buy 100g yarn for every 500g used 
Work on completing projects before starting new ones. Try to keep wips to 3 
Knit Soldotna top 
Knit Katniss Cowl 
Knit One of my Bluprint kits with Bristol Ivy 
Do a Fox paws scarf 
Crochet washcloths aiming for 52 as gifts 
Design something

About Me:

Born in South Africa, left for London when I was 21 where I traveled from for 2 years.  Then met an Aussie and now I would say my heart is totally Aussie, I love this country and being on the road in it. I would love to be on the road full time with yarn in my hand as much as possible.

I've taught myself to knit on YouTube and google but I just couldn't get the hang of teaching myself crochet.  Fortunately I met some wonderful friends from Europe on a volunteer construction project in Africa and they taught me how to crochet and since then I've been hooked! I keep referring to YouTube though on stitch and technique reminders.

**My measurements - 2019:**

Length of foot from back of heel to tip of toe: 24cm (9.5")
Leg circumference: 23.5cm (measurement taken at 15cm above ankle). In inches: 9.1/4" (measurement taken at 6" above ankle).
Ball of foot circumference: 21cm (8 1/4")

I've only ever knit one pair of proper socks (just finished) and they were toe-up so my cast on was 20sts for the pattern I had.

Head circumference 54cm (21")
Hand circumference over knuckles: 17.5cm (7")
Bust: 87cm (34")
Waist: 73cm (29")
Hips: 88cm (34.5")

**Colours I very strongly dislike:** Grey, Pastels, mauve, lilac although I will totally use these colours for gifts. It's just if it's something for me personally I have an aversion to them.

-----------------------
**Skills learned:**

**2020**
[Jeny's Surprisingly Stretchy Bind Off][5]
[I-Cord Grafting in the round][6]
[Tubular Sewn Bind Off in the Round][7]
[1x1 & 2x2 Tubular Cast On][8]
[Perfect Thumb Gusset Suzanne Bryan][9]
[German Short Rows][10]
[1/1/1 RPC or LPC without a Cable needle][11]
Began Intarsia (Basic)
[Shadow Short Wraps][12]

**2019**

**Knitting:**
Provisional cast on
Tubular Cast on (Lorilee Beltman)
Cables
Reading Charts
Socks Two At A Time (TAAT)
Socks toe-up
Double thickness head band on a hat (Wurm)
Cables without a cable needle 
Dropping down to repair a stitch (changing knit stitches to purl and vice versa)
[Dropping down and repairing M1 increases][13]
[Fixing a live dropped stitch after binding off][14] 
[Reverse duplicate stitch][15] (mainly for weaving ends in) 
[Alternative Cable Cast on][16]for Ribbing cast on - more stretching than just regular cast on
Smoother transition between ribbing and stockinette: 
For 2x2: Sl the Knit sts purlwise, Knit the Purls for the first row of stockinette 
For 1x1 Rib: Either the same as above or Knit 1 Below for the Knit sts, Knit the Purls for the first row of stockinette (https://youtu.be/bVLCXu8w3uM)
[Cat Bordhi's Toe Cast-on on DPNs][17]

[German Short Rows][18]


**Crochet:**
Bobble Stitch
Double crochet
How to keep my edges straight 
How to keep corners from curling on squares
Crocheting around front & back posts
Picking up stitches from the back bumps on a foundation chain (game changer!)

**Random Useful info:**

Golden Rule for neat edges – knit 1st stitch in back loop, slip last stitch purl wise with yarn in front (Tip from Marita Steyn from Beyond Knitting).

[How to make T-Shirt Yarn][19]
[Stretch-free crochet cord][20]

[Key for 2 Yarns held together][21]

Not sure if the following is correct but I noticed it on MsDonna’s profile and thought it could come in handy:

Double strand equivalents:

2 strands lace = fingering, 
1 strand lace and fingering = sport 
2 strands fingering = dk 
2 strands sport = worsted 
2 strands dk = bulky 
2 strands worsted = super bulky or thicker

Here’s what the book, Hip Knit Hats, says:

2 fingering= SPORT 
2 sport OR 1 sport+2 fingering= WORSTED 
3 sport OR 1 sport+1 worsted=HEAVY WORSTED 
1 worsted + 1 heavy worsted OR 1 worsted+ 2-3 sport=CHUNKY 
3 worsted OR 1 worsted+1chunky=BULKY

----------

BULKY created with following Possible Combinations:

1 strand of worsted weight with 2 strands of fingering/sock or lace weight
1 strand of aran or heavy worsted weight with 1 strand of fingering/sock or lace weight
4 strands of fingering/sock weight
1 strand of DK weight with 2-3 strands of fingering/sock or lace weight

Useful links:
[Alternative to Blocking wires BCF Mason wire][22]


Handy Sweater Size adjustment found on Tmesis profile:

Sweater size choice 
To determine which size to make, take the size you want to end up with (48”), multiply it by your gauge (14sts), then divide that number by the pattern gauge (13sts), to see that you would need to knit the 51.5” size. The calculation looks like this: (48x14)/13=51.6.

Choosing a size this way, though, does not take into account any row difference so you may have to account for that

**Margot’s Secret Blanket Bind-off**

https://www.ravelry.com/people/Margotchien
[https://www.ravelry.com/projects/Margotchien/picnic-time-14][23]
https://www.ravelry.com/projects/Margotchien/picnic-time-11

Assemble the squares of your blanket in your preferred manner (don’t worry about sewing in the ends – they will get folded into the bind-off.)

Knit binding:

With wrong side facing and with a bulky yarn (I used Snug), pick up every other stitch around all sides of your blanket.

Knit 3 more rounds.

On the fifth round, inc two stitches at each corner.

Knit one round.

On the seventh round, decrease two stitches at every corner.

Knit one round.

Begin bind-off:

a. Holding needle in left hand, and crochet hook in right hand, pick up one stitch with crochet hook on right side of blanket, in-line with your knitted on binding.
b. Do a single crochet with the stitch on the hook and the first stitch on the left hand needle (you will have one loop on your crochet hook.)
c. Repeat this move one time (you will have REVERSED DIRECTION and will be binding off in a counter-clockwise motion.) You now have two stitches on your crochet hook Do one single crochet.

Repeat a, b and c….all the way around your blanket, folding in the ends of you knitted squares as you go.

K5below
Video tutorial by designer: https://youtu.be/n1BWDLgjW3I

yoyo stitch tutorial
https://youtu.be/_jod51Vg4Y8

Carrying yarn up the side https://youtu.be/eeJfbIFWZlI
The most you should carry a yarn without wrapping it is 4 rows.

Bind-Off
Per designer, just use a regular bind-off but go up a needle size so it doesn’t get too tight.

Tidying up the last stitch of a bind-off
https://youtu.be/LntAEHQjigo

Seaming using the Mattress Stitch
https://youtu.be/46IUyefCkXA
The following video tells you how to fix it when one side that you’re seaming gets longer/shorter than the other:
https://youtu.be/ObuZwHlmDCI
https://youtu.be/wQnAfTmI0iA

Buttons made from yarn:
Wrap yard around size 13 needle 12 times, leaving ~6” tail.
-Take loops off needle and pull a loop thru with a Size D crochet hook and chain one.
-Make as many single crochets as will fit around circle. (keep top firm so it doesn’t bulge out when doing 2nd row)
-Join to first sc with a slip stitch, and chain 1
-Repeat with a second set of single crochets, going through the same center hole and covering the first set. (I put a removable marker in the first stitch)
-Join to beginning of round with a slip stitch and pull the yarn through.
-Use a tapestry needle to work both ends to the center, tie a square knot.
-Pull yarn thru knitted fabric front to back, bring back to front of fabric and use one end to wrap around and create shank. Tie a double knot under button and work ends up into button to hide.

I worked a chain up the other side, 4 chains per 5 stitches, and working a loose 5 stitch chain to create the buttonhole and attached it 4 rows up and continued chain to next buttonhole. 

  [1]: https://www.ravelry.com/discuss/australian-swappers/441736/426-450#450
  [2]: https://www.interweave.com/article/crochet/asymmetrical-shawls-10-styles/
  [3]: https://www.ravelry.com/groups/chubby-chic-knits/pages/Jacquard-Invisible-Floats
  [4]: https://blog.tincanknits.com/2013/10/03/kitchener-stitch/
  [5]: https://knitty.com/ISSUEfall09/FEATjssbo.php
  [6]: https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=xZvfXSQaF-8
  [7]: https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=p9jMhMgJEuU
  [8]: https://youtu.be/yE3b4Vq3sJ8
  [9]: https://youtu.be/RJQswKVPF5k
  [10]: https://www.purlsoho.com/create/german-short-rows/
  [11]: https://knotions.com/1-1-1-rpc-without-a-cable-needle/
  [12]: https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=9Bc23kdkZMo
  [13]: https://youtu.be/GW_xYJQqS_Y
  [14]: https://youtu.be/sjKdFg9AHXo
  [15]: https://youtu.be/UHUOkLOaFjs
  [16]: https://youtu.be/QDtcabyPQaI
  [17]: https://youtu.be/_Px2dxWHZ8U
  [18]: https://www.purlsoho.com/create/german-short-rows/
  [19]: https://youtu.be/181mzs3GFY0
  [20]: https://www.crochetspot.com/how-to-crochet-stretch-free-cord/
  [21]: https://orcasislandknitting.me/2017/10/21/key-for-two-yarns-together/
  [22]: https://www.bcf.com.au/p/mason-single-strand-wire/M110655.html
  [23]: https://www.ravelry.com/projects/Margotchien/picnic-time-14

Come and join our community in my Ravelry Group for pattern support, KALs (Knit-Alongs), test knits and new pattern announcements.

Please share your projects on Instagram @Knitwegian so we can show some love!

users.fave_colors: Greens (especially olive), oranges (rusts and pumpkin type oranges), yellows (especially mustard & Ochre), dark, vibrant teal. I love wearing shades of warm neutrals and brown. When it comes to other colours I like the  deep & rich tones.
users.about_me:
[APQ Link][1]

https://www.ravelry.com/wiki/pages/UsingTheTextEditor
[Ways to shape an Asymmetrical shawl][2]

**Techniques**
[Jacquard Invisible Floats][3]
[Kitchener Stitch][4]

**2020 goals**
Only buy 100g yarn for every 500g used 
Work on completing projects before starting new ones. Try to keep wips to 3 
Knit Soldotna top 
Knit Katniss Cowl 
Knit One of my Bluprint kits with Bristol Ivy 
Do a Fox paws scarf 
Crochet washcloths aiming for 52 as gifts 
Design something

About Me:

Born in South Africa, left for London when I was 21 where I traveled from for 2 years.  Then met an Aussie and now I would say my heart is totally Aussie, I love this country and being on the road in it. I would love to be on the road full time with yarn in my hand as much as possible.

I've taught myself to knit on YouTube and google but I just couldn't get the hang of teaching myself crochet.  Fortunately I met some wonderful friends from Europe on a volunteer construction project in Africa and they taught me how to crochet and since then I've been hooked! I keep referring to YouTube though on stitch and technique reminders.

**My measurements - 2019:**

Length of foot from back of heel to tip of toe: 24cm (9.5")
Leg circumference: 23.5cm (measurement taken at 15cm above ankle). In inches: 9.1/4" (measurement taken at 6" above ankle).
Ball of foot circumference: 21cm (8 1/4")

I've only ever knit one pair of proper socks (just finished) and they were toe-up so my cast on was 20sts for the pattern I had.

Head circumference 54cm (21")
Hand circumference over knuckles: 17.5cm (7")
Bust: 87cm (34")
Waist: 73cm (29")
Hips: 88cm (34.5")

**Colours I very strongly dislike:** Grey, Pastels, mauve, lilac although I will totally use these colours for gifts. It's just if it's something for me personally I have an aversion to them.

-----------------------
**Skills learned:**

**2020**
[Jeny's Surprisingly Stretchy Bind Off][5]
[I-Cord Grafting in the round][6]
[Tubular Sewn Bind Off in the Round][7]
[1x1 & 2x2 Tubular Cast On][8]
[Perfect Thumb Gusset Suzanne Bryan][9]
[German Short Rows][10]
[1/1/1 RPC or LPC without a Cable needle][11]
Began Intarsia (Basic)
[Shadow Short Wraps][12]

**2019**

**Knitting:**
Provisional cast on
Tubular Cast on (Lorilee Beltman)
Cables
Reading Charts
Socks Two At A Time (TAAT)
Socks toe-up
Double thickness head band on a hat (Wurm)
Cables without a cable needle 
Dropping down to repair a stitch (changing knit stitches to purl and vice versa)
[Dropping down and repairing M1 increases][13]
[Fixing a live dropped stitch after binding off][14] 
[Reverse duplicate stitch][15] (mainly for weaving ends in) 
[Alternative Cable Cast on][16]for Ribbing cast on - more stretching than just regular cast on
Smoother transition between ribbing and stockinette: 
For 2x2: Sl the Knit sts purlwise, Knit the Purls for the first row of stockinette 
For 1x1 Rib: Either the same as above or Knit 1 Below for the Knit sts, Knit the Purls for the first row of stockinette (https://youtu.be/bVLCXu8w3uM)
[Cat Bordhi's Toe Cast-on on DPNs][17]

[German Short Rows][18]


**Crochet:**
Bobble Stitch
Double crochet
How to keep my edges straight 
How to keep corners from curling on squares
Crocheting around front & back posts
Picking up stitches from the back bumps on a foundation chain (game changer!)

**Random Useful info:**

Golden Rule for neat edges – knit 1st stitch in back loop, slip last stitch purl wise with yarn in front (Tip from Marita Steyn from Beyond Knitting).

[How to make T-Shirt Yarn][19]
[Stretch-free crochet cord][20]

[Key for 2 Yarns held together][21]

Not sure if the following is correct but I noticed it on MsDonna’s profile and thought it could come in handy:

Double strand equivalents:

2 strands lace = fingering, 
1 strand lace and fingering = sport 
2 strands fingering = dk 
2 strands sport = worsted 
2 strands dk = bulky 
2 strands worsted = super bulky or thicker

Here’s what the book, Hip Knit Hats, says:

2 fingering= SPORT 
2 sport OR 1 sport+2 fingering= WORSTED 
3 sport OR 1 sport+1 worsted=HEAVY WORSTED 
1 worsted + 1 heavy worsted OR 1 worsted+ 2-3 sport=CHUNKY 
3 worsted OR 1 worsted+1chunky=BULKY

----------

BULKY created with following Possible Combinations:

1 strand of worsted weight with 2 strands of fingering/sock or lace weight
1 strand of aran or heavy worsted weight with 1 strand of fingering/sock or lace weight
4 strands of fingering/sock weight
1 strand of DK weight with 2-3 strands of fingering/sock or lace weight

Useful links:
[Alternative to Blocking wires BCF Mason wire][22]


Handy Sweater Size adjustment found on Tmesis profile:

Sweater size choice 
To determine which size to make, take the size you want to end up with (48”), multiply it by your gauge (14sts), then divide that number by the pattern gauge (13sts), to see that you would need to knit the 51.5” size. The calculation looks like this: (48x14)/13=51.6.

Choosing a size this way, though, does not take into account any row difference so you may have to account for that

**Margot’s Secret Blanket Bind-off**

https://www.ravelry.com/people/Margotchien
[https://www.ravelry.com/projects/Margotchien/picnic-time-14][23]
https://www.ravelry.com/projects/Margotchien/picnic-time-11

Assemble the squares of your blanket in your preferred manner (don’t worry about sewing in the ends – they will get folded into the bind-off.)

Knit binding:

With wrong side facing and with a bulky yarn (I used Snug), pick up every other stitch around all sides of your blanket.

Knit 3 more rounds.

On the fifth round, inc two stitches at each corner.

Knit one round.

On the seventh round, decrease two stitches at every corner.

Knit one round.

Begin bind-off:

a. Holding needle in left hand, and crochet hook in right hand, pick up one stitch with crochet hook on right side of blanket, in-line with your knitted on binding.
b. Do a single crochet with the stitch on the hook and the first stitch on the left hand needle (you will have one loop on your crochet hook.)
c. Repeat this move one time (you will have REVERSED DIRECTION and will be binding off in a counter-clockwise motion.) You now have two stitches on your crochet hook Do one single crochet.

Repeat a, b and c….all the way around your blanket, folding in the ends of you knitted squares as you go.

K5below
Video tutorial by designer: https://youtu.be/n1BWDLgjW3I

yoyo stitch tutorial
https://youtu.be/_jod51Vg4Y8

Carrying yarn up the side https://youtu.be/eeJfbIFWZlI
The most you should carry a yarn without wrapping it is 4 rows.

Bind-Off
Per designer, just use a regular bind-off but go up a needle size so it doesn’t get too tight.

Tidying up the last stitch of a bind-off
https://youtu.be/LntAEHQjigo

Seaming using the Mattress Stitch
https://youtu.be/46IUyefCkXA
The following video tells you how to fix it when one side that you’re seaming gets longer/shorter than the other:
https://youtu.be/ObuZwHlmDCI
https://youtu.be/wQnAfTmI0iA

Buttons made from yarn:
Wrap yard around size 13 needle 12 times, leaving ~6” tail.
-Take loops off needle and pull a loop thru with a Size D crochet hook and chain one.
-Make as many single crochets as will fit around circle. (keep top firm so it doesn’t bulge out when doing 2nd row)
-Join to first sc with a slip stitch, and chain 1
-Repeat with a second set of single crochets, going through the same center hole and covering the first set. (I put a removable marker in the first stitch)
-Join to beginning of round with a slip stitch and pull the yarn through.
-Use a tapestry needle to work both ends to the center, tie a square knot.
-Pull yarn thru knitted fabric front to back, bring back to front of fabric and use one end to wrap around and create shank. Tie a double knot under button and work ends up into button to hide.

I worked a chain up the other side, 4 chains per 5 stitches, and working a loose 5 stitch chain to create the buttonhole and attached it 4 rows up and continued chain to next buttonhole.

  [8]: https://youtu.be/yE3b4Vq3sJ8
  [9]: https://youtu.be/RJQswKVPF5k
  [10]: https://www.purlsoho.com/create/german-short-rows/
  [11]: https://knotions.com/1-1-1-rpc-without-a-cable-needle/
  [12]: https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=9Bc23kdkZMo
  [13]: https://youtu.be/GW_xYJQqS_Y
  [14]: https://youtu.be/sjKdFg9AHXo
